Solution to Question 1:
Homeostasis is called dynamic equilibrium because the body maintains an internal balance within fluctuating limits. It describes the maintenance of nearly constant conditions in the internal environment despite changes in the outside world.
A number of variables such as body temperature, blood sugar levels, blood pH, etc. are regulated within a range of values (homeostatic ranges) and not at fixed values.
These variables are not given equal importance. There is a hierarchy of importance so that the constancy of certain variables may be altered markedly to maintain others within their normal range. For example, respiratory or metabolic compensation to maintain blood pH.
The disruption of homeostasis either due to extreme environmental challenge or a breakdown of internal homeostatic mechanisms is termed as a disease.
Solution to Question 2:
Stimulus, receptor and effector are all components of a homeostatic control system. Components of homeostasis include:
Stimulus - It is a detectable change in the internal or external environment, such as change in temperature.
Receptor - It detects environmental changes.
Integrating centre
Effector - It is an organ or cell that acts in response to a stimulus.

Solution to Question 3:
Feedback regulation is seen in the increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood pressure. This is because, in feedback regulation, the homeostatic response (increased heart rate) occurs after the change (decrease in blood pressure) has occurred.
On the other hand, in feedforward regulation, the homeostatic responses take place before the change has occurred. This is done in anticipation of the change to minimize fluctuations.
Examples of feedforward regulation include:
The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins.
The smell of food triggers the secretion of salivary and gastric juices.
An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels.
Solution to Question 4:
Positive feedback is seen in all except gastric secretion. It is under negative feedback control.
Negative feedback consists of certain changes that affect a deficient or excessive variable to pull it back to a certain mean value to maintain homeostasis. Most processes in the body are under negative feedback. For example, an increase in gastric acids leading to a decrease in gastric secretion.
Positive feedback consists of changes that affect a variable to push it further away from a certain mean value. For example, an increase in LH leading to a further increase in LH. Instances, where positive feedback plays an important role are:
Clotting of blood
Calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
LH Surge
Action potential
Shock
Parturition

Cortisol is a steroid hormone. Adrenaline and thyroxine are derivatives of the amino acid tyrosine.
Solution to Question 2:
Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.
Thyroid hormones enter the nucleus and bind to thyroid hormone receptors. The
hormone-receptor complex in the nucleus binds to DNA via zinc fingers. This increases the expression of a variety of different genes that code for proteins regulating cell function. Although thyroxine is an AA derivative, there are transporters to move it into the cell, hence they are intracellular receptors acting on the nucleus.

Solution to Question 3:
Cortisol is not stored before release.
Usually, the polypeptide and protein hormones such as insulin, thyroxine or renin are stored in secretory vesicles before release. They are synthesized as much larger polypeptide chains (preprohormones) that are biologically inactive and then processed intracellularly by specific proteases to yield the final hormone molecule which is stored in the secretory vesicle until needed.
On the other hand, steroid hormones such as cortisol are synthesised as needed and are not stored. They are lipid soluble and easily diffuse across cell membrane to enter the interstitial fluid and then blood.
Solution to Question 4:
Downregulation of receptors occurs due to internalisation, inactivation of receptors or desensitisation.
A decrease in the level of stimulating hormones generally leads to an increase in the level of active receptors. This is called upregulation of receptors.
On the other hand, an increase in the level of stimulating hormones generally leads to a decrease in the level of active receptors. This is called downregulation of receptors.
Downregulation of receptors can occur by one of the following mechanisms:
Desensitisation - Receptors undergo chemical modifications that make them less responsive.
Internalisation - It is the temporary sequestration of the cell membrane receptors to the inside of the cell, away from the action of hormones. Following internalisation, the receptors are either destroyed or recycled.
Inactivation of receptors.
Decreased production of receptors.

Nicotinic cholinergic receptors activate an ion channel after binding with its agonist. These receptors are called ligand-gated channels or ionotropic receptors.
Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and function. They are:
Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors)
When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in ionic conductance.
Important for fast synaptic transmission.
Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype).
G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors)
When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated channels on neuronal membranes.
Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 5HT3) and opioid receptors.

G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in  subunit.
G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors.
G proteins have 3 subunits ( , and ■). In its resting state,  subunit is bound to GDP.
Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates G protein within the cell. The  subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such as cAMP, cGMP or Ca2+.
Once the ligand is unbound, the intrinsic GTPase activity of the  subunit converts GTP to GDP. This leads to reassociation of  with the -■ subunit and termination of effector activation.

Equilibrium potential for an ion is calculated using the Nernst equation.
When there is a concentration gradient for an ion across the membrane, the ion tends to diffuse down the concentration gradient. The electric potential that exactly opposes this net diffusion is called the equilibrium potential for that ion. This is calculated using the Nernst equation.
It is expressed as the potential inside the cell (intracellular potential relative to the extracellular potential).

This equation is used only to derive the numerical value of the potential. It is NOT used to derive the sign/charge (+/-).
The sign/charge is derived from logic:
In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater outside, then the + ion moves from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively. Hence, the potentia will be positive.
In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater inside, then the + ion moves from inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively (as + ion moves outside). Hence the potential will be negative.
In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater outside, then the - ion moves from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively. Hence the potential will be negative.
In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater inside, then the - ion moves from inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively (as - ion moves outside). Hence the potential will be positive.

Sweating loss of water Hyperosmotic volume contraction
The osmolarity of ECF increases because sweat is hyposmotic (relatively more water than salt is lost).
ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume in the sweat.
Water shifts out of ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity increases until it is equal to ECF smolarity, and ICF volume decreases.
Plasma protein concentration increases because of the decrease in ECF volume. Although hematocrit might also be expected to increase, it remains unchanged because of the water shifts out of the RBCs, decreasing their volume and offsetting the concentrating effect of the decreased ECF volume.
So,Loss of hypotonic fluid causes hypertonic volume contraction.

In a spinal motor neuron, initiation of nerve impulse occurs in the axon hillock and initial segment of the axon because it has a very high density of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels. Hence, this region is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential.
Parts of a Neuron:

Dendritic zone where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated.
Axon hillock: part of the cell body from which the axon arises.
Initial segment: the first part of the axon where propagated action potentials are generated.
An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings. The unmyelinated regions of a myelinated axon are termed as nodes of Ranvier.

Note: Action potentials are generated at the initial segment in spinal motor neurons and the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons.

The spatial distribution of ion channels along the axon plays a key role in the initiation and regulation of action potential.

From a functional point of view, neurons generally have four important zones :
A receptor, or dendritic zone, where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated
A site where propagated action potentials are generated (the initial segment in spinal motor neurons, the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons)

Solution to Question 6:
The conduction velocity of a myelinated axon increases linearly with diameter. Conduction velocity is increased by:
Increasing the fiber size: Increasing the diameter of a nerve fiber results in decreased internal resistance; thus, conduction velocity down the nerve is faster.
Myelination: Myelin acts as an insulator around nerve axons and increases conduction velocity. Myelinated nerves exhibit saltatory conduction. It is a rapid process that allows myelinated axons to conduct up to 50 times faster than the fastest unmyelinated fibers.
Activity of the Na+–K+ pump does not directly affect the formation or conduction of action potentials.
Solution to Question 7:
The graph depicts action potential. The movement of Na+ into the cell is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3.
Once the membrane is depolarized to the threshold, local potential, the upstroke of the nerve action potential is caused by the opening of the Na+ channels. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. When the Na+ channels open, Na+ moves into the cell down its electrochemical gradient, driving the membrane potential toward the Na+ equilibrium potential.

The process responsible for repolarization is the opening of K+. The K+ permeability becomes very high and drives the membrane potential toward the K+equilibrium potential by the flow of
K+ out of the cell.
Solution to Question 8:
The membrane conductance for potassium is maximum during repolarization (marked as point 3 in the above image).
Most of the increase in K+ conductance comes after the increase in Na+ conductance around the time of repolarization.

During the early portion of the action potential, the sodium conductance is 1000 times greater than potassium conductance. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.
When the membrane potential rises from 90 millivolts toward zero, this voltage change causes a conformational change in the K+ channels which allows increased potassium efflux. Then, the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels begin to open, and potassium conductance begins to increase (and sodium conductance decreases).
The increased flow of K+ out of the cell causes membrane repolarization. The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state explains the after-hyperpolarization followed by a return to the resting membrane potential.
Solution to Question 9:
Regarding the upstroke of a nerve action potential, there is a net inward current and the cell interior becomes less negative. The direction of the current is either
same as the direction of positive charge ( eg, Na+ )
opposite to the direction of negative charge (eg, Cl- )
opposite to the direction of electrons
Since Na+ moves in, there is a net inward current.
Since the RMP increases, the cell interior becomes less negative.
In response to a depolarizing stimulus, some of the voltage-gated Na+ channels open and Na+ enters the cell and the membrane is brought to its threshold potential. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. The rapid upstroke in the membrane potential ensues. So, there is a net influx of Na+, and the interior of the cell becomes positive during the upstroke of the action potential.

Solution to Question 10:
The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state also explains the after-hyperpolarization.
In response to a depolarizing stimulus, some of the voltage-gated Na+ channels open and Na+ enters the cell. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. The rapid upstroke in the membrane potential ensues.
The membrane potential moves toward the equilibrium potential for Na+ (+60 mV) but does not reach it during the action potential, primarily because the increase in Na+ conductance is
short-lived. The Na+ channels rapidly enter a closed state called the inactivated state and remain in this state for a few milliseconds.
In addition, the direction of the electrical gradient for Na+ is reversed during the overshoot because the membrane potential is reversed, and this limits Na+ influx; also the voltage-gated K+ channels open. These factors contribute to repolarization. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels is slower and more prolonged than the opening of the Na+ channels. The net movement of positive charge out of the cell due to K+ efflux at this time helps complete the process of repolarization.
The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state also explains the after-hyperpolarization, followed by a return to the resting membrane potential.
Thus, voltage-gated K+ channels bring the action potential to an end and cause closure of their gates through a negative feedback process.
Note: Na+ channels: Positive feedback loop; K+ channels: Negative feedback loop.



Solution to Question 11:
The refractory period is the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus. It can be absolute or relative.
During the rising and much of the falling phases of the spike potential, the neuron is refractory to stimulation. This refractory period is divided into an
Absolute refractory period, corresponding to the period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete
Relative refractory period, lasting from this point to the start of after-depolarization During the absolute refractory period, no stimulus, no matter how strong, will not excite the
nerve. However, during the relative refractory period, stimuli that are stronger than normal can cause excitation.
The absolute refractory period for large myelinated nerve fibers is about 1/2500 second.
Solution to Question 12:
The relative refractory period starts from one-third of repolarization till the start of after-depolarization.
The refractory period is a period during which another normal action potential cannot be elicited in an excitable cell.
Solution to Question 13:
The rheobase is an indicator of the magnitude of the current. It is the minimum intensity (strength/magnitude) of stimulation required to generate an action potential when the stimulation is of infinite duration.
Utilization time is the minimum time (duration) for which the rheobase has to be applied for the excitation of tissue.
Chronaxie is the minimum time (duration) for which a stimulus double the strength of rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue.


Strength-duration curve gives the idea of the excitability of a tissue.
Strength-duration relationship arises because the same minimum electrical charge necessary to excite an action potential can come from a current that is either brief but large or prolonged but small. It is the product of strength and duration that determines excitability, and thus these two parameters are inversely related in their effectiveness.
Note: Chronaxie is a better index than rheobase and utilization time for comparing the excitability of a tissue.
Solution to Question 14:
Slowly rising subthreshold currents fail to fire the nerve due to a process called accommodation, which is a type of adaptation.
Accommodation is due to inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels. Due to the slow rise of stimulus, only a few voltage-gated Na+ channels are activated at a time. Wallerian degeneration
If the axon is cut, the part distal to the cut degenerates; this process is called as Wallerian degeneration.
Orthograde degeneration (Wallerian degeneration) occurs from the point of injury to the nerve terminal, interrupting neural transmission.
After the injury, the membrane breaks down and the myelin sheath degenerates. The cell body of the injured neuron swells, the nucleus moves to an eccentric position, and the rough endoplasmic reticulum becomes fragmented (chromatolytic reaction).
The nerve then starts to regrow, with multiple small branches projecting along the path the axon previously followed (regenerative sprouting).

Voltage-gated sodium channels have 3 states that you can find them in. They can either be closed, open, or inactive.
When the stimulus causes activation of the open gates, sodium rushes into the cell causing the membrane potential to become more positive. The sequence of events during the action potential occur in 7 steps as described below.
Resting state - Both channels are closed
Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters into the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
The sodium influx causes opening of more sodium channels through positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.
Sodium conductance decreases.
Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.
Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period. It is the frequency at which individual muscle fibres twitch that fuse and cause sustained muscle contraction, where the contraction period is the time taken from latent period to maximum force of contraction.
In this case, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means the tracer recorded 100 waves per second.
Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.
In the image given in the question, between the point B (end of latent period) to point C
(maximum force of contraction), there are about 5 waves. Hence, the duration of contraction = 5 x 0.01 = 0.05 seconds. Substituting the value in the formula, we get:
Tetanizing frequency = 1/0.05 sec = 100/5 = 20/sec.

Tetanization:
The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:
by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ■ber summations.
by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.
When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous,
this is called tetanization. Beyond this point, a further increase in the frequency, will not result in increased force of contraction.
Tetanization occurs in two ways:
Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

When the action potential reaches the muscle fiber, there is influx of Ca2+ ions. This Ca2+ binds to troponin C and tropomyosin is moved out of the way. Myosin heads can now bind to actin and form so-called cross-bridges.
When a head attaches to an active site, this attachment simultaneously causes profound changes in the intramolecular forces between the head and arm of its cross-bridge. This causes the head to tilt toward the arm and to drag the actin filament along with it. This tilt of the head is called the power stroke.

A feature of the myosin head that is essential for muscle contraction is that it functions as an adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) enzyme.
Chemical Events during Muscle Contraction
Before contraction begins, the heads of the cross-bridges bind with ATP. The ATPase activity of the myosin head immediately cleaves the ATP but leaves the cleavage products, ADP plus phosphate ion, bound to the head. (Point A)
When the troponin-tropomyosin complex binds with calcium ions, active sites on the actin filament are uncovered and the myosin heads then bind with these sites. (Point B)
The bond between the head of the cross-bridge and the active site of the actin filament causes a conformational change in the head and the power stroke occurs. (Point C)
Once the head of the cross-bridge tilts, the ADP and phosphate ion that were previously attached to the head are released and a new ATP moelcule binds in that place. (Point D)
The binding of the new ATP molecule causes detachment of the head of myosin from the actin. (Point D)
This cycle is then repeated.

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.
The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:
Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarisation.
The depolarization of the muscle fibre causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.
Steps in relaxation:
The cytoplasmic calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, by the action of SERCA (sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase).
Once the calcium concentration is lowered, the interaction between actin and myosin ceases, and the muscle relaxes.

Neurotransmitter receptors that act through second messenger systems are called metabotropic receptors.
Neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the post-synaptic membrane to activate ion channels in one of the two ways:
by gating ion channels directly (ionotropic receptors).
by activating a second messenger (metabotropic receptor) for a prolonged postsynaptic neuronal excitation or inhibition. Most commonly activated is a G-protein coupled membrane receptor.
The following four changes can occur usually after binding to a G-protein coupled receptor:
Opening specific ion channels through the post-synaptic cell membrane.
Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) or cyclic guanosine monophosphate
(cGMP) in the neuronal cell.
Activation of one or more intracellular enzymes.
Activation of gene transcription. Activation of gene transcription is one of the most important effects of activation of the second messenger systems because gene transcription can cause formation of new proteins within the neuron, thereby changing its metabolic machinery or its structure.

At the post-synaptic membrane, neurotransmitters binding to receptors generate responses that can be excitatory or inhibitory. If it generates an excitatory response (makes the membrane more electrically positive/ depolarized), it is an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) because it makes the cell more likely to reach an action potential.
EPSP may be due to
The opening of sodium channels or calcium channels to allow large numbers of positive electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell.
Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels or both.
Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.

Solution to Question 13:
Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to the influx of chloride ions (Cl-).
If, binding of a neurotransmitter causes the postsynaptic membrane to become more negative (hyperpolarized), it is called an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) because hyperpolarization moves the membrane potential farther from the threshold and makes the cell less likely to reach an action potential.
IPSP may be due to :
Increase in Cl- influx. This action causes diffusion of negatively charged chloride ions from outside the postsynaptic neuron to the inside, thereby carrying negative charges inward and increasing the negativity inside. This leads to hyperpolarization.
Increase in K+ efflux. This action causes positive ions to diffuse to the exterior, which causes increased negativity inside the neuron, which leads to hyperpolarization.
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

Denervation Supersensitivity:
When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.
Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.
Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it.
This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter.

The relative tactile acuity of a given region can be determined by the two-point discrimination test. Here, calipers are used to determine the minimum distance between the two points which can be perceived as two points. Greater the density of receptors  Smaller the receptive field  More precise the localization.
For e.g., Stimulus points on the back, for instance, must be separated by at least 65 mm before they can be distinguished as separate, whereas on the fingertips two stimuli are recognized if they are separated by as little as 2 mm. The lips have the greatest acuity (two-point discrimination threshold ~ 1 mm).
Clinical significance:
Blind individuals benefit from the tactile acuity of fingertips to facilitate the ability to read Braille. The dots forming Braille symbols are separated by 2.5 mm.
Two-point discrimination is used to test the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus) system.

Solution to Question 6:
Mechanoreceptors and exteroceptors have the same classification of receptors.

Nociceptors are pain receptors which detect physical and chemical damage occuring in the tissue. Interoceptors are concerned with the internal environment.
Chemoreceptors are receptors stimulated by a change in the chemical composition of the environment in which they are located. These include receptors for taste and smell as well as visceral receptors such as those sensitive to changes in the plasma level of O2, pH, and osmolality.
Teleceptors (distance receivers) are concerned with events at a distance, example -
photoreceptors.
Proprioceptors provide information about the position of the body in space at any given instant.

Solution to Question 16:
Visceral pain is poorly localized, unpleasant and associated with nausea and autonomic symptoms. It often originates from thoracic and abdominal cavities, transmitted through small type C pain fibers.
It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex.
When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is called the dermatomal rule.
Example: the heart and the arm have the same segmental origin.

Alveoli are pain insensitive structures. Alveoli of lungs and parenchyma of liver are almost completely insensitive to the pain of any type.

Solution to Question 18:
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) of pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate A and A fibers near the injury to relieve pain.
Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
The relief may result from inhibition of pain pathways (Inhibition of C fibers and A-delta fibers) in the dorsal horn gate, by stimulation of large-diameter touch-pressure afferents(A-beta fibers). This is called the gate-control hypothesis.
Interesting clinical application: Touching or shaking an injured area decreases the pain due to the injury. Stimulation with an electric vibrator at the site of pain also gives some relief.
The same mechanism is probably responsible for the efficacy of counterirritants. Stimulation of the skin over an area of visceral inflammation produces some relief of the pain due to the visceral disease. The old-fashioned mustard plaster works on this principle.

Solution to Question 1:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law.
Laws in Sensory Physiology
Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

A cortical homunculus is a distorted representation of the human body, based on a neurological map of the areas and proportions of the human brain dedicated to processing motor functions, or sensory functions, for different parts of the body. The size of the cortical receiving area for impulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part.

Solution to Question 11:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.
Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.
The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.
The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.
Damage to the corticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.
Solution to Question 12:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side.
Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.
Clinical features:
Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla).
Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the leve of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

Solution to Question 13:
The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex do not pass directly to the anterior motor neurons; instead, they first pass into the spinal cord interneuron pool of neurons and only secondarily to the motor neurons. The shortest possible circuit is a three- or four-neuron pathway. The following basic types of circuits are present:
Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal;
Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits; and
Circuits to cause after-discharge are present. They prolong the reflex contraction of the muscles that last many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over.

The flexor reflex is organized to withdraw a pained or otherwise irritated part of the body from a stimulus. Further, because of after-discharge, the reflex can hold the irritated part away from the stimulus for 0.1 to 3 seconds after the irritation is over. During this time, other reflexes and actions of the central nervous system can move the entire body away from the painful stimulus.

Solution to Question 15:
The cell bodies of  and  motor neurons to a given muscle lie close together. Both types are activated by interneurons in their immediate vicinity and sometimes directly by neurons of the descending pathways. During many voluntary and involuntary movements, they are coactivated, i.e., they are excited at almost the same time. ( -■ coactivation)
The purpose of  -■ coactivation:
First, it keeps the length of the receptor portion of the muscle spindle from changing during th course of the whole muscle contraction. Hence, the muscle contraction is not opposed by th stretch reflex.
Second, if the muscle spindle did not contract and relax along with the large muscle fibers, th receptor portion of the spindle would sometimes be flail and sometimes be overstretched.
Coactivation thus ensures that information about muscle length will be continuously available to provide for adjustment during ongoing actions and to plan and program future movements.

The remaining 20% make up the ventral corticospinal tract. These fibers remain uncrossed until reaching the spinal cord where axons terminate bilaterally on spinal interneurons antecedent to motor neurons. These fibers control the movements of the axial musculature.

Mass Reflex: In a spinal animal or human being, sometimes the spinal cord suddenly becomes excessively active, causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. The usual stimulus that causes this excess activity is a strong pain stimulus to the skin or excessive filling of a viscus, such as over-distention of the bladder or the gut. The mass reflex involves large portions or even all of the cord.
The effects are as follows:
A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasms;
The colon and bladder are likely to evacuate;
The arterial pressure often rises to maximal values, sometimes to a systolic pressure well over 200 mm Hg; and
Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating.
The mechanism is similar to the mechanism of epileptic seizures, which involve reverberating circuits that occur in the brain instead of in the cord.

Solution to Question 1:
When dynamic -motor neurons are activated at the same time as  -motor neurons to muscle, the number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is greater than when  discharge alone is increased.
When  – coactivation occurs, intrafusal and extrafusal fibers shorten together, and spindle afferent activity can occur throughout the period of muscle contraction.

The gamma efferent system is excited by signals from the bulboreticular facilitatory region of the brain stem.
When the bulboreticular facilitatory region transmits excitatory signals through the gamma nerve fibers to the intrafusal muscle fibers of the muscle spindles, it shortens the ends of the spindles and stretches the central receptor regions, thus increasing their signal output. If the spindles on both sides of each joint are activated at the same time, then reflex excitation of the skeletal muscles on both sides of the joint increases, producing tight, tense muscles opposing each other at the joint. The net effect is that the position of the joint becomes strongly stabilized.
Any time a person must perform a muscle function that requires a high degree of delicate and exact positioning, the bulboreticular facilitatory region of the brain stem stabilizes the positions of the proximal joints.

Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of dysmetria which is most commonly found due to a lesion involving the cerebellum or the cerebellar pathways. Therefore, a lesion in the spinocerebellar tract is most likely to be found in this patient.
Dysmetria - In the absence of the cerebellum, the subconscious motor control system cannot predict how far movements will go. Therefore, the movements ordinarily overshoot their intended mark; then the conscious portion of the brain overcompensates in the opposite direction for the succeeding compensatory movement. Dysmetria also results from lesions in the spinocerebellar tracts because feedback information from the moving parts of the body to the cerebellum is essential for cerebellar timing of movement termination.
Solution to Question 14:
Dysdiadochokinesia—Inability to Perform Rapid Alternating Movements.
In cerebellar lesions, the motor control system fails to predict where the different parts of the body will be at a given time. As a result, the succeeding movement may begin much too early or much too late and no orderly “progression of movement” can occur.
So, a series of stalled attempted but jumbled movements occurs instead of the normal coordinated movements. This condition is called dysdiadochokinesia.
Solution to Question 15:

Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): The oldest part of the cerebellum which contains nodulus in the vermis and the flanking flocculus. It has vestibular connections and is concerned with equilibrium and gait. Loss of it can cause disturbance of equilibrium and postural movements, especially during rapid movements.
Spinocerebellum: The region that receives proprioceptive input from the body as well as a copy of the “motor plan” from the motor cortex. By comparing the plan with performance, it smooths and coordinates movements that are ongoing. Superior vermis is a part of spinocerebellum. Loss of it can cause problems with coordination.
Cerebrocerebellum: They are the newest from a phylogenetic point of view, reaching their greatest development in humans. They interact with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements.

Solution to Question 19:
The excitatory fibers in the cerebellum are climbing fibers, mossy fibers, and granule cell parallel fibers.
The fundamental circuits of the cerebellar cortex :
Climbing fibers exert a strong excitatory effect on single Purkinje cells. Mossy fibers exert an excitatory effect on granule cells.
Each granule cell sends an axon to the molecular layer, where the axon bifurcates to form a T. The branches of the T are straight and run long distances; thus, they are called parallel fibers. The parallel fibers form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of many Purkinje cells.
The other neurons (basket cells, stellate cells, and golgi cells) are inhibitory interneurons. Basket cells and stellate cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and each inhibits many Purkinje cells. Golgi cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and mossy fibers. Their axons project to the dendrites of the granule cells where they form an inhibitory synapse.
The output of the Purkinje cells is ultimately inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

The mechanism of action of surfactant is by breaking the structure of water in alveoli.
When water forms a surface with air, the water molecules on the surface of the alveoli have a strong attraction for one another. This pulls the molecules together, leading to high surface
tension.
The surfactant is amphipathic in nature (i.e., hydrophobic on one end and hydrophilic on the other). They align themselves on the alveolar surface, with their hydrophobic portions facing the alveolar lumen.
The cohesive force between a water molecule and an adjacent pulmonary surfactant molecule is very low. So, they break up the attracting forces between water molecules lining the alveoli (which had been responsible for the high surface tension). Thus, they reduce surface tension.

Transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) is the difference between alveolar pressure (Palv) and intrapleural pressure (Pip). It is given by the formula: Ptp = Palv-Pip. Inspiration causes a negative change in both the Palv and Pip. Lung compliance is the extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure.
In a normal adult, the pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O of both lungs together. Hence, expanding the lungs by 200 mL of inspired air will require an increase in Ptp by 1 cm H2O.
Given:
Pulmonary compliance = 0.2 L/cm H2O = 200 ml/cm H20 Alveolar pressure at the beginning of inspiration = 4 cmH2O Intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration = -5 cmH2O Volume of air inhaled = 600mL (0.6L)
Step 1: Calculate the initial transpulmonary pressure (Ptp).
Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Intrapleural pressure; Initial transpulmonary pressure = 4 cmH2O - (-5 cmH2O) = 9 cmH2O
Step 2: ˜se the lung compliance formula to find the change in transpulmonary pressure. Lung compliance = Change in volume / Change in transpulmonary pressure.
Pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O. Hence, to expand the lungs by 200 mL of inspired air, it will require an increase in Ptp by 1 cm H2O. So, for 600 ml inspired air, the compliance is = 600 mL / 200 mL/cm H2O = 3 cmH2O
Step 3: Calculate the transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) after inhaling 600mL of air.
During inspiration, the alveolar pressure (Palv) decreases, and the intrapleural pressure (Pip)
becomes more negative.
Final transpulmonary pressure = Initial transpulmonary pressure + change in transpulmonary pressure; Final transpulmonary pressure = 9 cmH2O + 3 cmH2O = 12 cmH2O.

A liquid-ventilated lung is more compliant compared to a gas-ventilated lung.

The difference in the curves generated during inflation and deflation, termed hysteresis, is not present in the saline-generated curves.

Solution to Question 15:
During moderate exercise, there is no change in arterial pO2, arterial pCO2 or arterial pH.
Ventilation increases abruptly at the onset of exercise due to psychic stimuli and afferent impulses from proprioceptors in muscles, tendons, and joints. This is followed by a brief pause and then a gradual increase in ventilation. This gradual increase in ventilation is believed to be due to multiple factors such as an increase in body temperature, increase in plasma K+ level stimulating peripheral chemoreceptors, or the sensitivity of the neurons controlling the response to CO2.
In strenuous exercise, at a certain point, the O2 uptake reaches its maximum levels, beyond which it cannot increase further. This leads to a rise in blood lactate levels. Buffering of lactic acid liberates CO2 which further increases ventilation. The increased production of lactic acid, increase in ventilation and CO2 production are proportional, and alveolar and arterial CO2 changes little to nil. This is called isocapnic buffering.

Solution to Question 2:
Transport of CO is diffusion limited because of the high affinity of CO to hemoglobin. Diffusion across the alveolocapillary membrane:
Blood takes 0.75s to traverse pulmonary capillaries.
CO diffuses into blood and combines with Hb with very high affinity. Thus the partial pressure of CO doesn't rise (Only dissolved form of gas can increase the partial pressure, Gas which combines with Hb or plasma proteins cannot). Partial pressure gradient necessary for diffusion of CO is maintained for the whole 0.75s and hence it is Diffusion limited.
In the case of N2O it does not react and reaches equilibrium in about 0.1s. The amount of N2O taken up is not limited by diffusion but by the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries; that is, it is Flow-limited.
O2 is intermediate between N2O and CO; it is taken up by haemoglobin, but much less avidly than CO, and it reaches equilibrium with capillary blood in about 0.3 s. Thus, its uptake is Perfusion-limited.
In the case of perfusion limited gases, an increase in pulmonary blood flow increases the amount of gas transferred. Hence O2 transport increases with an increase in pulmonary blood flow.

Solution to Question 14:
Facilitation of oxygen transport depends on the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, explained by the Bohr effect.
When the metabolic activity of tissues increases, the production of CO2 increases. This CO2 diffuses into the blood and in turn, raises the blood H2CO3 and causes an increase in the H+ concentration and a decrease in pH. This decreases the affinity of Hb for O2, shifting the O2- hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This facilitates the unloading of O2 in the tissues. The effect of Pco2 and pH on O2 hemoglobin dissociation curve is called the Bohr Effect.
Conversely, in the lungs, CO2 diffuses from the blood to the alveoli and the H+ concentration decreases and theO2 hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left increasing the affinity of Hb to O2.
Note:
Double Bohr effect occurring in the placenta: Oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve of fetal blood and maternal blood move in opposite directions.
Mechanism:
The fetal blood entering the placenta carries large amounts of carbon dioxide, but most of it diffuse from the fetal blood into the maternal blood.
Fetal blood - loss of CO2 - reduced H+ - shift to left - loading of O2 i.e. oxygenation of fetal Hb.
Maternal blood - increase in CO2 - increase in H+ - shift to the right - Release of oxygen.

Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.

The inspiratory flow-volume curve is truncated in patients with variable extrathoracic obstructions.

During a forced expiration, the cross-sectional area of a variable extrathoracic obstruction increases as the pressure inside the airway increases.
The expiratory flow-volume curve is therefore nearly normal or not affected.

Solution to Question 1:
Hypoxic hypoxia is characterized by low partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2), while other parameters like partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2) may remain normal.
Ventilation–Perfusion Imbalance:
The patchy ventilation–perfusion imbalance is the most common cause of hypoxic hypoxia or hypoxemia.
If alveoli are not ventilated but perfusion is present - blood passing through that alveoli remains unoxygenated.
When this unoxygenated blood mixes with blood from normal or overventilated alveoli, there is a right to left shunt created.
This results in reduced partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (PaO2) i.e., hypoxemia and consequently hypoxia.
Note:
Hypoxemia can be defined as a condition where arterial oxygen tension or partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is below normal.
Hypoxia is defined as the reduction of oxygen supply at the tissue level, which is not measured directly by a laboratory value.
Scenario 1:
Generally, the presence of hypoxemia suggests hypoxia i.e. if there is less oxygen in blood, O2 supply to tissues will also be reduced.
But, in case of cyanide poisoning, there is hypoxia in the absence of hypoxemia, i.e., arterial O2 content is normal but tissues are not able to utilize it because cyanide interferes with aerobic metabolism in the tissues.
Scenario 2:
Hypoxia may not be present in patients with hypoxemia if the patient compensates for a low PaO2 by increasing oxygen delivery. This is typically achieved by increasing cardiac output (by raising the heart rate) or decreasing tissue oxygen consumption.
Nevertheless, hypoxemia is definitely the most common cause of tissue hypoxia, and the correct diagnosis should be made because it is readily treatable.
Solution to Question 2:
In the case of anemic hypoxia, O2 content is low but dissolved O2 is within normal limits, so it does not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.
Peripheral chemoreceptors located in the carotid and aortic arteries sense changes in Po2(<60mm Hg), pH, and Pco2 and they respond to changes in dissolved O2(PaO2).

Administration of oxygen-rich gas has limited value in anemic, histotoxic, and stagnant hypoxia because:
Anemic hypoxia- Oxygen delivery is not beneficial because despite increasing the exogenous oxygen delivery, an anemic person will not have the capacity to carry more oxygen due to the hemoglobin/ red blood cell deficit in anemia.
Histotoxic hypoxia- The most common example is cyanide poisoning. Cyanide inhibits important enzymes in the oxidative phosphorylation process, which is essential to the survival of our cells. Additional oxygen supplementation will not be able to overcome this inhibition, and so it will have limited benefit. Hyperbaric oxygen may be helpful to some extent.

Solution to Question 11:
Decompression sickness is seen in pilots, mountaineers, and divers.
Decompression sickness (DCS) or diver’s disease, the bends, or Caisson disease is the name given to a variety of symptoms experienced by a person exposed to a reduction in the pressure surrounding their body.
It can be seen in
Divers ascending rapidly from deep-sea (high pressure) to the surface of the earth (low pressure)
Pilots traveling in unpressurized aircraft or mountaineers, rapidly ascending from the surface of the earth (high-pressure zone) to a high altitude (low-pressure zone).
Under high-pressure, gases get compressed and their solubility increases. When a person is in a high-pressure zone like the deep sea for a long time, an increased amount of nitrogen gets
dissolved in his or her body. If the person suddenly comes back to an area of atmospheric pressure or a low-pressure zone, the gases escape from a dissolved state and form bubbles. These bubbles are almost entirely made of nitrogen. The bubbles can plug many small blood vessels in different tissues.
Solution to Question 12:
Nitrogen narcosis is due to increased solubility of nitrogen in the nerve cell. Concept:
Below the sea level, atmospheric pressure increases at the rate of 1 atm for every 33 feet depth.
According to Boyle’s law, as pressure increases, volume decreases. Hence, lungs tend to collapse. To prevent this and to keep lung expanded, gas is delivered at high pressure to the lungs.
According to Dalton’s law, nitrogen contributes the maximum to barometric pressure and hence the amount of nitrogen entering alveoli increases.
Henry’s law: As the partial pressure of nitrogen in alveoli increases, its concentration in blood also increases (dissolved form). Nitrogen is 5 times more soluble in fat compared to water.
As a result, nitrogen dissolves in the fatty substances in neuronal membranes, and because of its hysical effect on altering ionic conductance through the membranes, it reduces neuronal excitability and produces the narcotic effect.

On ascension to higher altitudes over a period of days rather than a period of hours, the ability to breathe much more deeply and withstand lower atmospheric O2 concentrations is improved. This phenomenon is called acclimatization.
Variation of pH in Acclimatization:
Immediate exposure to low pO2 stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors. This increases alveolar ventilation. This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the pCO2 and increases the pH of the body fluids.
These changes inhibit the brain stem respiratory center and thereby oppose the effect of low PO2 to stimulate respiration through the peripheral arterial chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies.
There is a reduction of bicarbonate ion concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid, as well as in the brain tissues. This reduction, in turn, decreases the pH in the fluids surrounding the chemosensitive neurons of the respiratory center, thus increasing the respiratory stimulatory activity of the center. An important mechanism for the gradual decrease in bicarbonate concentration is compensation by the kidneys for the respiratory alkalosis. Gradually, the metabolic compensation of the kidney will shift the pH towards normal.
Solution to Question 14:
The symptoms of headache and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness and IV digoxin is not used to treat this condition.
On ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and the following symptoms are seen:
Headache
Irritation
Insomnia
Breathlessness
Nausea and vomiting
Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.
Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high altitude areas

A note on inspiratory ramp signal:
The neural signals transmitted to the inspiratory muscle, mainly the diaphragm, is not the instantaneous burst of action potentials. Instead, it begins weakly and increases steadily in a ramped manner. The advantage of the ramp is that it causes a steady increase in the volume of the lungs during inspiration, rather than inspiratory gasps.
Control of the limiting point at which the ramp suddenly ceases is the mechanism by which the respiratory centers control depth and rate of respiration.

Solution to Question 17:
Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.
Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues. This is done by the enzyme -glutamyl carboxylase with the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor.
This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin.
Hence, warfarin indirectly inhibits the -carboxylation of vitamin K dependent clotting factors
- Factors II, VII, IX, X by directly inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. Thus leading to decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in these factors.

Solution to Question 18:
Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. From here, the blood enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This mixed blood is distributed to the body via aorta.
Therefore, inferior vena cava has the highest concentration of oxygen in the fetal circulation.

Solution to Question 17:
Mayer waves are due to the variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure.
The most important mechanisms are as follows:
I: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor reflex:
High pressure excites the baroreceptors -->inhibits sympathetic nervous system and lowers the pressure -->The decreased pressure, in turn, reduces the baroreceptor stimulation
-->elevating the pressure to a high value (the response is not instantaneous, it is delayed until a few seconds later). This high pressure then initiates another cycle, and the oscillation continues.
II: Oscillation of the CNS Ischemic Response:
The cerebrospinal fluid pressure is raised to 160 mm Hg --> causes compression of cerebral blood vessels --> cerebral ischemia--> CNS ischemic pressure response raises the arterial pressure up to 200mm Hg -->the brain ischemia is relieved and the sympathetic nervous system becomes inactive -->the arterial pressure falls rapidly back to a much lower value, causing brain ischemia once again -->initiates another rise in pressure. This chain of events repeats itself cyclically as long as the cerebrospinal fluid pressure remains elevated.

Events of the Cardiac Cycle Diastole
Protodiastole
Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
Iso-volumetric Relaxation
The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
Ventricular Filling
Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
Atrial Systole
During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.
Systole
Isovolumetric Contraction
The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
Ventricular Ejection
When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively.

Solution to Question 25:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge reflex.
Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex
The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain.
Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.
Bezold-Jarisch Reflex:
Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary egion of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound brady- cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.
Cushing Reflex:
When ICP is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised.
The local hypoxia and hypercapnia causes an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration.
The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Phase 0 of pacemaker potential is initiated by opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. The pacemaker potential consists of:
Phase 0 - this is upstroke seen due to the opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. This causes an influx of calcium leading to the upstroke.
Phase 3 - This is followed by inactivation of the calcium channels and simultaneous activation of K+ channels. This leads to efflux of K+ bringing about repolarization.
Phase 4- As the K+ efflux declines, a channel permeable to both Na+ and K+ opens leading to an influx of both Na+ and K+. This is the If channel. This is responsible for slow spontaneous diastolic depolarization. This accounts for the automaticity of SA and AV node.
The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

Solution to Question 23:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.
The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent
signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and
pulmonary circulation. Other options:
Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound bradycardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing.
Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.
Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.
Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:
Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

Solution to Question 19:

Bile contains bile acids, bile salts, bile pigments, phospholipids, water, and electrolytes. It is secreted by the liver and concentrated in the gall bladder.
Two primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes. When these primary bile acids are secreted into the lumen of the intestine, a portion of each is converted to secondary bile acids (deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid) by bacteria.
The liver conjugates primary and secondary bile acids with glycine or taurine to their respective bile salts. Ex: Glycocholic acid, Taurodeoxycholic acid.
Rate of bile secretion is 30 - 60 mL/hour (500 - 1000 mL/day). Note: Bile has no digestive enzymes.
Solution to Question 20:
Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts.
The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine

The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.

Solution to Question 1:
Salivary amylase is activated by Cl-.
Human salivary and pancreatic amylases are activated by chloride (Cl–). They have optimum activities near-neutral pH (7.4). They hydrolyze internal 1:4 linkages but spare 1:6 linkages and terminal 1:4 linkages in starch.
Solution to Question 2:
Digestion of disaccharides occurs in the small intestine.
The enzymes maltase, sucrase, isomaltase, lactase, and trehalase are located in the
enterocytes covering the intestinal microvilli brush border. The disaccharides are digested into their constituent monosaccharides as they come in contact with these enterocytes.
Solution to Question 3:
Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport.
On the basolateral side, there is active transport of sodium ions out of the cell into the interstitial fluid. This depletes sodium inside the cell. Because of this Na+ concentration difference, more Na+ binds to the SGLT on the luminal side. This increases the affinity of SGLT for glucose and glucose binds to it.
Then, both the Na+ and glucose are transported together to the interior of the cell. Thus, glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. The energy for glucose transport is provided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the cell. The glucose moves out of the cell into the blood across the basolateral membrane by facilitated diffusion mediated via GLUT.

Solution to Question 4:

Option B: SGLT1 is involved in the absorption of glucose into the enterocyte. SGLT2 is responsible for glucose transport out of the renal tubules.
Option D: GLUT1 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organs.

Both salivary and the pancreatic  -amylases hydrolyze internal 1:4 linkages but spare 1:6 linkages and terminal 1:4 linkages of starch.

çymogens (proenzymes) are inactive precursors of the enzymes. Most of the peptidases (proteases) are present in the form of proenzymes. Trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, proelastase, procarboxypeptidase A, procarboxypeptidase B are zymogens.

Solution to Question 7:

All proenzymes are converted to their active form by selective proteolysis (removal of a few amino acids).
Enterokinase cleaves trypsinogen to yield active trypsin. It is located on the brush border of duodenal enterocytes.

Solution to Question 8:
The synthesis and secretion of proteases as catalytically inactive proenzymes protect the normal pancreas from autodigestion.
All the protease proenzymes present in the pancreatic juice get converted to their active form only in the small intestinal lumen (site of action).
If proenzymes get activated in the pancreas (site of origin), they can digest the entire pancreas within a few hours, giving rise to the condition called acute pancreatitis.
Solution to Question 9:
Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase, not endopeptidase. Peptidases (proteases) are of two types:
Endopeptidases - they act at interior peptide bonds in the peptide molecules. Ex- pepsin, trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase.
Exopeptidases - they hydrolyze the amino acids at the carboxyl ends of the polypeptides, one at a time. Ex- carboxypeptidase, aminopeptidase.
Solution to Question 10:
Peptide transporter 1 (PepT1) is involved in the absorption of the dipeptide.
The dipeptides and tripeptides are transported along with H+ into enterocytes by a system known as peptide transporter 1 (PepT1).
These peptides undergo intracellular hydrolysis to release amino acids. These amino acids are absorbed into the circulation from the basolateral membrane via basolateral amino acid transporter. H+ moves out of the cell via Na+-H+ exchanger on the luminal side.

Solution to Question 11:
Lipids are passively absorbed in the gut.
The products of lipid digestion (monoglycerides and free fatty acids) are incorporated into micelles that are formed by bile salts and diffuse across the intestinal epithelium. Short and medium-chain fatty acids can directly diffuse across the intestinal epithelium.
Note: Recent evidence suggests that specific carrier proteins (membrane transporters) may be involved in the transport of long-chain fatty acids.

Most of the iron in the diet is in the ferric (Fe3+) form, whereas it is the ferrous (Fe2+) form that is absorbed.
Note: Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids are absorbed throughout the length of the small intestine. Bile acids are present throughout the small intestine, but active absorption occurs only in the ileum, and active absorbtion of folate occurs in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).
Solution to Question 19:
Elemental iron stimulates ferritin synthesis.
It synthesizes ferritin by causing the release of a cytoplasmic protein that binds to a specific region in the ferritin mRNA. This disruption activates ferritin mRNA and results in its translation.
Hepcidin binds to ferroportin and triggers its internalization and degradation. This results in decreased iron absorption and decreased circulating iron levels which reduces ferritin synthesis.

Note: Ferritin sequesters Fe2+, a potentially toxic molecule.
Solution to Question 20:
Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption.
It is named for its originally described property as a hepatocellular protein with bactericidal activities.
Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.

Solution to Question 1:
The interstitial cells of Cajal undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that periodically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that generate
slow-wave activity.
Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.
In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.
The slow waves usually do not by themselves cause muscle contraction in most parts of the gastrointestinal tract, except perhaps in the stomach. Instead, they mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction.
Note: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.
Solution to Question 2:
Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).
The Basal electrical rhythm (BER) also called slow-wave, is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. It is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV.
The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.
The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:
Stomach: 4/min
Duodenum: 12/min
Distal ileum: 8/min
Cecum: 2/min
Sigmoid colon: 6/min
The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension.
Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle
tension. Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

Muscle contraction can occur only when the motor stimulus is provided during the depolarisation part of the BER.
Thus, BER does not cause muscle contraction by itself, but controls the rate and organization sites of the muscle contractions, as in coordination of the peristaltic activity and setting the rhythm of segmentation.

Among the given options, the frequency of 'slow waves' is maximum in the ileum (8/min).
Normal intestinal motility is determined by two patterns of electrical activity - slow waves and spike potentials.
Slow waves, also known as basic electrical rhythm are partial depolarizations of smooth muscle cells, spreading along the GIT. They originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal. The smooth muscles are in a hyperpolarized state, having a resting membrane potential of -50 to -60mV.
These waves are not action potentials themselves and they do not cause any contractions. Slow waves raise the membrane potential by 5-15mV, bringing it closer to the threshold enabling spike potential (true action potential) to occur. Therefore, they set the basic rhythm of GIT.

Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by enteric reflexes.
Regulation of gastric emptying is mainly by the inhibitory feedback signals from the duodenum that includes enterogastric reflex and hormonal feedback by cholecystokinin.
Enterogastric reflex: When food enters the duodenum, multiple nervous reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall. They strongly inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.
These reflexes are mediated by three routes:
Directly from the duodenum to the stomach through the enteric nervous system in the gut wall

Through inhibitory sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach (minor role)
Vagus nerves to the brain stem where they inhibit the normal excitatory signals transmitted to the stomach (minor role)

Duodenal slow waves are generated in the duodenum at a rate of about 10 per minute, which carry down the small bowel.
The amplitude of these contractions increases to a maximum in phase III, which lasts for about 10 minutes. This 90-minute cycle of activity is then repeated.

The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches zero.
However, in addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The property can be studied by using charged dextran.

For substances that are actively reabsorbed or secreted, there is a limit to the rate at which
the solute can be transported, which is referred to as the transport maximum. This limit is due to saturation of the specific transport systems involved.
Normally, measurable glucose does not appear in the urine because essentially all the filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.
The transport maximum for glucose is about 375 mg/min, whereas the filtered load of glucose is only about 125 mg/min. With large increases in GFR and/or plasma glucose concentration
that increase the filtered load of glucose above 375 mg/min, the excess glucose filtered is not reabsorbed and passes into the urine.
When the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/100 ml and the filtered load is at its normal level (125 mg/min) there is no loss of glucose in the urine. However, when the plasma concentration of glucose rises above about 200 mg/100 ml, increasing the filtered load to about 250 mg/min, a small amount of glucose begins to appear in the urine. This point is termed as the threshold for glucose.
Splay is due to separation between filtered load and exceretion. It occurs due to different transport maximums of different nephrons.

Solution to Question 12:

Filtered Load: The filtered load of PAH increases linearly as the unbound concentration of PAH increases (filtered load = GFR. [P]PAH).
Secretion: At low concentrations of PAH, many carriers are available and secretion increases linearly as the plasma concentration increases. When the PAH concentration increases to a level where the carriers are saturated, Tm is reached. After this point, no matter how much the PAH concentration increases, there can be no further increase in the secretion rate.
Excretion. For a secreted substance such as PAH, excretion is the sum of filtration and secretion. At low PAH concentrations (below Tm), excretion increases steeply with increases in plasma PAH concentration because both filtration and secretion are increasing. At PAH concentrations above Tm, excretion increases less steeply (and parallels the curve for filtration) because only the filtration component increases as concentration increases; secretion is already saturated.

Solution to Question 32:
Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule.

The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts:
Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the dista tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.
