Solution to Question 3:
Normal anion gap is mostly due to unmeasured proteins.
Normally in the plasma, the concentrations of anions and cations are equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Thus no real "anion gap" exists in the plasma and this is purely a diagnostic concept.
Diagnostically, when the electrolytes are measured in the blood, routinely only certain cations and anions are measured. These are Na+, Cl- and HCO3-. The anion gap is the difference between the unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations. This is estimated as :
Plasma anion gap= [Na+] - [Cl-] - [HCO3-]
The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium.
The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulphate and organic anions. This is primarily used in measurement of different causes of metabolic acidosis.
Solution to Question 4:
The normal anion gap ranges between 8 and 16 mEq/L.
The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma.
However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl and HCO3.
The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations and is estimated as
Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ]  [HCO3 ]  [Cl ]=14424108 =12 mEq/L
The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall.
The most important unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium and the major unmeasured anions are albumin, phosphate, sulfate and other organic anions.
Usually the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations and the anion gap ranges between 8 and 16 mEq/L.

Micturition Reflex
Micturition is fundamentally a spinal reflex facilitated and inhibited by higher brain centers and is subject to voluntary facilitation and inhibition.
These centers include
trong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pon
everal centers located in the cerebral cortex that is mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory.
The micturition reflex is the basic cause of micturition, but the higher centers normally exert final control of micturition.
Micturition Reflex is the result of a stretch reflex initiated by sensory stretch receptors in the bladder wall, especially by the receptors in the posterior urethra when this area begins to fill with urine at the higher bladder pressures.
Sensory signals from the bladder stretch receptors are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then reflexively back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers by way of these same nerves. (refer figure)
As the bladder continues to fill, the micturition reflexes become more frequent and cause greater contractions of the detrusor muscle.
Once a micturition reflex begins, it is “self-regenerative.”
It is a single complete cycle of
The progressive and rapid increase of pressure,
A period of sustained pressure, and
Return of the pressure to the basal tone of the bladder.
As the bladder becomes more and more filled, micturition reflexes occur more and more often and more and more powerfully.
Once the micturition reflex becomes powerful enough, it causes another reflex, which passe through the pudendal nerves to the external sphincter to inhibit it. If this inhibition is more potent in the brain than the voluntary constrictor signals to the external sphincter, urination will occur. If not, urination will not occur until the bladder fills still further and the micturition reflex
becomes more powerful.

Solution to Question 20:

Cystometrogram (refer figure)
A plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder is called a cystometrogram.
The curve shows
An initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced(Ia);
A long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced(Ib);
A sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II).
The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.
This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius.
P= 2T/R
In the case of the bladder, the tension increases as the organ fill but so does the radius. Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full.

Step 2: HCO3- is 12 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3- levels decrease.

Step 3: As per Winter's formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can be calculated using,
pCO2 =( 1.5 x [HCO3-] ) +8 ± 2
In this case, Expected pCO2 = ( 1.5 x [12] ) +8 ± 2
= 26 ± 2
= 24 - 28 mmHg
The pCO2 in this patient is 18 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis contributing to reduced pCO2.

Solution to Question 16:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.
Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone:
Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter
Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by follicular cells.
Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions:
Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine) in the presence of H2O2
Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3
(triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood
Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone

Solution to Question 5:
Glucose-mediated insulin release occurs through the closure of ATP sensitive K+ channels. Therefore the new drug being initiated is most probably a sulfonylurea which acts via a similar mechanism.
Increased blood glucose concentration is the primary controller of insulin secretion. Inside the beta cells, glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate and later ATP is generated. This ATP closes ATP sensitive potassium channels, leading to a rise in K+ and depolarization. This in turn causes the opening of voltage-gated Ca 2+ channels and influx of Ca+. This ultimately leads to the secretion of insulin via exocytosis.

Diazoxide keeps the ATP sensitive K+ channels open and prevents depolarization, resulting in a decreased insulin release. It is used in patients with insulinoma.
Sulfonylureas cause closure of the ATP sensitive K+ channels, leading to increased insulin secretion. It is used in patients with diabetes mellitus.

Most of the other GLUT transporters are not insulin sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane. Ex: GLUT-1 in RBCs, brain and kidneys. (GLUT-3 is also present in the brain and kidneys)
Note: Insulin promotes glucose uptake in the liver. However, this is done by increasing the activity of glucokinase and inactivating glycogen phosphorylase. The net effect is the synthesis of glycogen and decreased breakdown of glycogen.

Solution to Question 17:
Sperm motility is increased by vaginal secretions.
On coming in contact with the fluids of the female genital tract, multiple changes occur that activate the sperm for the final processes of fertilization. These collective changes are called capacitation of the spermatozoa, which normally requires from 1 to 10 hours.
The following changes are believed to occur:
The uterine and fallopian tube fluids wash away the various inhibitory factors that suppress sperm activity in the male genital ducts.
While the spermatozoa remain in the fluid of the male genital ducts, they are continually exposed to many floating vesicles from the seminiferous tubules containing large amounts of cholesterol. This cholesterol is continually added to the cellular membrane covering the sperm acrosome, toughening this membrane and preventing the release of its enzymes.
After ejaculation, the sperm deposited in the vagina swim away from the cholesterol vesicles upward into the uterine cavity, and they gradually lose much of their other excess cholestero during the next few hours. In doing so, the membrane at the head of the sperm (the acrosome) becomes much weaker.
The membrane of the sperm also becomes much more permeable to calcium ions, so calcium now enters the sperm in abundance and changes the activity of the flagellum, giving it a powerfu whiplash motion in contrast to its previously weak undulating motion. In addition, the calcium ions cause changes in the cellular membrane that cover the leading edge of the acrosome, making it possible for the acrosome to release its enzymes rapidly and easily as the sperm penetrates the granulosa cell mass surrounding the ovum, and even more so as it attempts to penetrate the zona pellucida of the ovum.

The follicular phase, during which a mature follicle and secondary oocyte develop; and

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: the menstrual phase, the proliferative phase, and the secretory, or progestational, phase
Menstrual phase: This phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris from the vagina.
It coincides with the end of the ovarian luteal phase and onset of a new follicular phase.
Withdrawal of progesterone on the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL) leads simultaneously to sloughing of the endometrium (menstruation) and development of new follicles in the ovary under the influence of rising gonadotropic hormone levels
Proliferative Phase: Thus, menstrual flow ceases, and the proliferative phase of the uterine cycle begins concurrently with the last portion of the ovarian follicular phase.
When the menstrual flow ceases, a thin endometrial layer less than 1-mm thick remains. Estrogen stimulates proliferation of epithelial cells, glands, and blood vessels in the endometrium, increasing this lining to a thickness of 3 to 5 mm.
The estrogen-dominant proliferative phase lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. Peak estrogen levels trigger the luteinizing hormone (LH) surge responsible for ovulation.
Secretory or Progestational Phase: After ovulation, when a new corpus luteum is formed, the uterus enters the secretory, or progestational, phase, which coincides in time with the ovarian luteal phase. The corpus luteum secretes large amounts of progesterone and estrogen.
Progesterone converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, glycogen-filled tissue.
This period is called either the secretory phase, because the endometrial glands are actively secreting glycogen into the uterine lumen for early nourishment of a developing embryo before it
implants, or the progestational (“before pregnancy”) phase, referring to the development of a lush endometrial lining capable of supporting an early embryo after implantation.
If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

Luteal phase: the corpus luteum secretes large quantities of progesterone and estrogen. They exert a negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary gland causing the suppression of both FSH and LH secretion.
Preovulatory period: The high level of estrogens at this time (or the beginning of progesterone secretion by the follicles) causes a positive feedback stimulatory effect on the anterior pituitary leading to a surge of LH and to a lesser extent, FSH.
Follicular phase: secretion of estrogen, progesterone from the corpus luteum decreases which leads to loss of negative feedback effect of these hormones on the anterior pituitary. Therefore, pituitary secretion of FSH begins to increase again, as much as twofold. LH secretion increases slightly as well.

Solution to Question 3:
The phosphagen system is utilized by the muscles of the athlete's body during a dash race.
The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run. Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.
Energy systems:
The phosphocreatine-creatine system: The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds.
The glycogen–lactic acid system: can provide 1.3 to 1.6 minutes of maximal muscle activity.
The aerobic system: The aerobic system is the oxidation of foodstuffs in the mitochondria to provide energy. It can sustain mucle activity for an unlimited time (as long as nutrients last).
Solution to Question 4:
Slow-twitch fibres, which are adapted for endurance running, are not larger in diameter than fast-twitch fibres. Fast-twitch fibres are about twice as large in diameter compared with
slow-twitch fibres.
Fast-Twitch and Slow-Twitch Muscle Fibers
Fast-twitch fibres can deliver extreme amounts of power from a few seconds to a minute.
The enzymes that promote rapid release of energy from the phosphagen and glycogen–lactic acid energy systems are more active in fast-twitch fibres.
Fast-twitch fibres are about twice as large in diameter compared with slow-twitch fibres.
Gastrocnemius muscle has a higher preponderance of fast-twitch fibres, which gives it the apability of forceful and rapid contraction of the type used in jumping.
Slow-twitch fibres are mainly organized for endurance, especially for the generation of aerobi energy.
They have far more mitochondria than do the fast-twitch fibres.
They contain considerably more myoglobin. The extra myoglobin increases the rate of diffusion of oxygen throughout the fibre.
The enzymes of the aerobic metabolic system are considerably more active in slow-twitch fibres.
The number of capillaries is greater in the vicinity of slow-twitch fibres.
Soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibres and therefore is used to a greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.
Solution to Question 5:
Signals from joint proprioceptors play a role in stimulating the respiratory drive during exercise. Regulation of respiration in exercise
During strenuous exercise, O2 consumption and CO2 for mation can increase as much as 20- fold. Yet in the healthy athlete, the arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH remain almost exactly
normal. This is because the alveolar ventilation increases along with the increased level of oxygen metabolism.
Part of this stimulation of alveolar ventilation results from direct stimulation of the respiratory enter by nervous signals. An additional part is believed to result from sensory signals transmitted into the respiratory center from the contracting muscles and joint proprioceptors.
During strenuous exercise, the utilization of O2 in the entire body can increase to 75% to 85%. So, essentially all the oxygen is given to the exercising muscles leading to an increased
arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration.

Solution to Question 6:
The fall in blood bicarbonate levels is compensatory, and it helps increase the exercise effort, not hinder it.
Adaptation at High Altitudes
The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake. (Option B)
Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids (Respiratory alkalosis). This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder the maximal exercise effort. (Option C).
To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. This removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration.
Hence the fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort. NOTE
Lactic acid causes extreme fatigue. (Option D)
Ordinarily, the pyruvic acid from glycolysis enters the mitochondria of muscle cells and reacts with oxygen to form many ATP molecules.
However, when there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid then is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.
Solution to Question 7:
Smoking causes no change to the sensitivity of the chemoreceptors. Effect of Smoking on Pulmonary Ventilation in Exercise
Nicotine causes constriction of the terminal bronchioles of the lungs, which increases the resistance of air flow into and out of the lungs.
The irritating effects of the smoke causes increased fluid secretion into the bronchial tree and some degree of swelling of the epithelial linings, which again increases airflow resistance.
Nicotine paralyzes the cilia on the surfaces of the respiratory epithelial cells. As a result, much debris accumulates in the passageways, and this adds further to the difficulty in breathing.
All these factors together make even a light smoker experience respiratory strain during maximal exercise, and their level of performance may be reduced.
In persons with severe emphysema, as much as four-fifths of the respiratory membrane can be destroyed; then, even the slightest exercise can cause respiratory distress. Chronic smoking is an important cause of emphysema.

Almost all the energy released by the body’s metabolism of nutrients is eventually converted into body heat. Since metabolism rises significantly during exercise there is an increase in the body temperature. This increase in body temperature is significant and even lethal conditions such as heatstroke can easily develop in an athlete.

Solution to Question 16:
The respiratory quotient is 0.8.
The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization.
In the given question, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the O2 consumption is 250mL/min.
Therefore,
Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8
The respiratory quotient (R•) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.
When carbohydrates are metabolized with one molecule of oxygen, one carbon dioxide molecule is released. Therefore, the R• of carbohydrates = 1.
When fats are oxidized, for every 100 molecules of oxygen consumed, 70 molecules of CO2 are released. Therefore, the R• of fats is 0.70.
Similarly, the respiratory quotient for proteins is 0.80.
